availability.p: This work is the property of the McClung Museum, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN. It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text.

bibl.title: [Drawing of the posthole pattern of a mid-18th century Cherokee townhouse at Mialoquo, created in 1977] / [by Marion Drescher]
bibl.author: Drescher, Marion
bibl.note: This is a drawing of a posthole pattern of an 18th century Cherokee winter townhouse at Mialoquo. Overhill townhouses were situated in a common village plaza. There was generally a winter townhouse, which was a large circular dome in which a fire could be built in the center and an adjacent rectangular open pavilion for summer use. Both were used for public social and political activity. Excavations of Mialoquo were conducted by the University of Tennessee in 1977 as part of the Tellico Archaeological Project in anticipation of the flooding of the Lower Little Tennessee River by the Tellico Dam Reservoir. The excavations were conducted under contract with the National Park Service and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Principal investigator, Jefferson Chapman. Field Director, Gerald F. Schroedl.
Frank H. McClung Museum Photographic Collection

projectDesc.p: Prepared for The University of Tennessee Digital Library

figure.figDesc: Drawing of posthole pattern of Cherokee townhouse at Mialoquo, mid-18th century. Excavations by University of Tennessee, 1977. Drawing by Marion Drescher. This information was provided by the Frank H. McClung Museum.
